Excellent suggestion. Also, you can list the concrete contributions you made to the work as well. This is fairly common on more senior academic CVs but for job positions (not papers) and allows you to highlight the significance of your work in relationship to the paper and outcomes related to it.

But, yeah, screw the idea that authorship is precious like this. If you removing your contributions would have made the paper objectively worse, then in my book there is no excuse not to have someone as a co-author.

text: If the readers of this are CS profs, then they would have the cultural norm that a graduate student who wrote code and analyzed data would be the first author (in part because in CS writing code and analyzing data is the primary contribution of the paper) I was shocked and appalled in this very channel when I learned about the attitude held by econ professors towards the labor of their students. I wouldn't expect CS professors to know that senior PhD students in econ don't have any papers because of this abuse.
